unnormalised: Hey guys, someone asked me about train travel in India, and honestly, it’s an experience! I’ve travelled quite a bit, mostly 2nd AC, sometimes 3rd AC if the budget's tight. My longest journey was from Guwahati to Mumbai, took almost 50 hrs!
normalised: Hey guys, someone asked me about train travel in India, and honestly, it’s an experience! I’ve travelled quite a bit, mostly second A-C, sometimes third A-C if the budget's tight. My longest journey was from Guwahati to Mumbai, took almost fifty hours!

unnormalised: The Indian Railways website, irctc.co.in, is your best friend for booking. Book in advance, especially during holidays like Diwali or Dussehra. Tatkal tickets are an option, but they get snatched up fast. I remember once I booked a ticket from Delhi to Kolkata on 10/10/2023 - total mad rush to get confirmed status.
normalised: The Indian Railways website, I-R-C-T-C dot C-O dot I-N, is your best friend for booking. Book in advance, especially during holidays like Diwali or Dussehra. Tatkal tickets are an option, but they get snatched up fast. I remember once I booked a ticket from Delhi to Kolkata on tenth October two thousand and twenty three - total mad rush to get confirmed status.

unnormalised: Don't forget to download the "Where is my train?" app – super useful for tracking your train's location. I always check if my train, say the Rajdhani Express (12301), is running on time. Platform announcements can be confusing, especially at crowded stations like Kanpur Central.
normalised: Don't forget to download the "Where is my train?" app – super useful for tracking your train's location. I always check if my train, say the Rajdhani Express (one two three zero one), is running on time. Platform announcements can be confusing, especially at crowded stations like Kanpur Central.

unnormalised: Food on the train can be hit or miss. Sometimes I order from vendors through the app (costs about Rs. 200-300 per meal), but often I just carry snacks and chai. Speaking of chai, you’ll find vendors yelling “Chai, chai, garam chai!” at every station. A cup usually costs ₹10.
normalised: Food on the train can be hit or miss. Sometimes I order from vendors through the app (costs about rupee two hundred to three hundred per meal), but often I just carry snacks and chai. Speaking of chai, you’ll find vendors yelling “Chai, chai, garam chai!” at every station. A cup usually costs rupee ten.

unnormalised: Overall, Indian Railways is an adventure. Just be prepared for delays, crowds, and the occasional interesting co-passenger. Safe travels! Just remember to check for your PNR status to know what you're getting into.
normalised: Overall, Indian Railways is an adventure. Just be prepared for delays, crowds, and the occasional interesting co-passenger. Safe travels! Just remember to check for your P-N-R status to know what you're getting into.
